commit_message:
Freezerclient use "token" to authentication is not success

1. When auth_type ='token',loader.load_from_options(**kwargs) is
   not defined these parameters:
   tenent_name, user_domain_id, user_domain_name
2. The class of freezerclient.client.Client add "token" parameter.

Change-Id: I0b320a608677bcac2b6226330f902365a27b58d5

subject: Check whether a directory specific for this OS flavour (release+version) exists, and use that to pull the list of packages from, if available. Debian release version numbers consist of two numbers, <major>.<point>. For the current version of Stretch, at the point of this writing, the number is "9.5". The algorithm first tries to find a directory called "debs-Debian-9.5", then "debs-Debian-9", and then "debs". If one of these directories exists, it needs to contain the packages lists. For Ubuntu, the package lists are all in "debs".
messages:
[{'account_id': 27027, 'date': '2018-10-19 19:49:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2018-10-24 04:07:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

I'm not really feeling this to be honest.  

Firstly it duplicates everything which seems very unnecessary and super prone to bitrot.  

When parsing these files/ we have the "dist:" matcher where you can specify that a particular entry is for a given distribution -- we should be using that (if it's not meeting needs, then modifying that).

Before we go down the path inventing anything ourselves, we should really look at adopting bindep.  all this files/ stuff pre-dates it, but it has become the standard way of specifying dependencies for openstack and gives us all options of platform matching, etc.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-19 19:49:06.000000000', 'message': 'Check whether a directory specific for this OS flavour
(release+version) exists, and use that to pull the list
of packages from, if available. Debian release version
numbers consist of two numbers, <major>.<point>. For
the current version of Stretch, at the point of this
writing, the number is "9.5". The algorithm first tries
to find a directory called "debs-Debian-9.5", then
"debs-Debian-9", and then "debs". If one of these
directories exists, it needs to contain the packages
lists. For Ubuntu, the package lists are all in
"debs".

As a side effect, package lists may now be completely
independent on a per-release basis, so this patch also
installs "build-essential" instead of just gcc and g++.

Also, the package fixes the authentication problem in
Debian, as the code always assumes a TCP connection to
the database, but the standard Debian setup is to only
allow a Unix domain socket for management purposes.

Co-Authored-By: j.harbott@x-ion.de
Change-Id: I854d6d0e870a8c18a32353ab3fb20e440fb94969
'}]
commit_message:
Check whether a directory specific for this OS flavour
(release+version) exists, and use that to pull the list
of packages from, if available. Debian release version
numbers consist of two numbers, <major>.<point>. For
the current version of Stretch, at the point of this
writing, the number is "9.5". The algorithm first tries
to find a directory called "debs-Debian-9.5", then
"debs-Debian-9", and then "debs". If one of these
directories exists, it needs to contain the packages
lists. For Ubuntu, the package lists are all in
"debs".

As a side effect, package lists may now be completely
independent on a per-release basis, so this patch also
installs "build-essential" instead of just gcc and g++.

Also, the package fixes the authentication problem in
Debian, as the code always assumes a TCP connection to
the database, but the standard Debian setup is to only
allow a Unix domain socket for management purposes.

Co-Authored-By: j.harbott@x-ion.de
Change-Id: I854d6d0e870a8c18a32353ab3fb20e440fb94969

for some reason I feel this is way extra work to restrict vnic types, if it was done this way to have backward compatibility then it could be different situation, but the clean and simple way I'd suggest is to add a configuration parameter support_vnics for each mechanism type, then in code replace the supported_vnics with what are defined in config or else keep the default values ? that way its backward compatible and not huge changes needed and sounds way simpler than this."}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2018-10-13 09:21:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

> for some reason I feel this is way extra work to restrict vnic
 > types, if it was done this way to have backward compatibility then
 > it could be different situation, but the clean and simple way I'd
 > suggest is to add a configuration parameter support_vnics for each
 > mechanism type, then in code replace the supported_vnics with what
 > are defined in config or else keep the default values ? that way
 > its backward compatible and not huge changes needed and sounds way
 > simpler than this.

By default, every mech driver will be initialized with a list of supported VNICs (OVS, SR-IOV). This list is (almost) static [1].
In case the admin wants to deploy a specific OVS back-end (DPDK, HW offload, etc), the conf variable "vnic_type_blacklist" can be populated. But this is not common; most admins will use kernel OVS by default and this variable won't be needed (or any other config variable).

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/601600/14/neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/openvswitch/mech_driver/mech_openvswitch.py@71'}, {'account_id': 17120, 'date': '2018-10-13 16:12:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

> > for some reason I feel this is way extra work to restrict vnic
 > > types, if it was done this way to have backward compatibility
 > then
 > > it could be different situation, but the clean and simple way I'd
 > > suggest is to add a configuration parameter support_vnics for
 > each
 > > mechanism type, then in code replace the supported_vnics with
 > what
 > > are defined in config or else keep the default values ? that way
 > > its backward compatible and not huge changes needed and sounds
 > way
 > > simpler than this.
 > 
 > By default, every mech driver will be initialized with a list of
 > supported VNICs (OVS, SR-IOV). This list is (almost) static [1].
 > In case the admin wants to deploy a specific OVS back-end (DPDK, HW
 > offload, etc), the conf variable "vnic_type_blacklist" can be
 > populated. But this is not common; most admins will use kernel OVS
 > by default and this variable won't be needed (or any other config
 > variable).
 > 
 > [1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/601600/14/neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/openvswitch/mech_driver/mech_openvswitch.py@71

rather than having static list we can define a parameter in configuration lets say whitelist_nics or supported_nics and during initialization it will look if those are defined in config, if yes then set supported_nics, and if they're not there then use existing default values, this blacklist thing is convoluted.

supp_nics = cfg.CONF.get("whitelist_nics", group="ovs"):
if supp_nics:    
    self.supported_nics = supp_nics
else:
    self.supported_nics = [existing_defaults]

its pretty simple ?'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2018-10-13 19:00:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

> rather than having static list we can define a parameter in
 > configuration lets say whitelist_nics or supported_nics and during
 > initialization it will look if those are defined in config, if yes
 > then set supported_nics, and if they're not there then use existing
 > default values, this blacklist thing is convoluted.
 > 
 > supp_nics = cfg.CONF.get("whitelist_nics", group="ovs"):
 > if supp_nics:
 > self.supported_nics = supp_nics
 > else:
 > self.supported_nics = [existing_defaults]
 > 
 > its pretty simple ?

I understand your point, but:
- As I said, the VNIC list supported by default is almost static.
- We should avoid adding more configuration variables, if this is not needed.'}, {'account_id': 8313, 'date': '2018-10-15 18:36:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 8313, 'date': '2018-10-15 18:38:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8313, 'date': '2018-10-15 18:41:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Manjeet: thanks for suggesting improvements, could you please check the original comment from Bence (rubasov):
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/601600/2/neutron/conf/plugins/ml2/drivers/mech_sriov/agent_common.py@62
Here he suggested to use blacklist, and I feel that from admin's perspective this is quite good, as no way that the admin accidentaly tries to change the behaviour of a mech driver by adding something which is not in the default driver specific supported_vnic_types list."}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2018-10-15 20:09:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

Build succeeded.

- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/601600/15 : SUCCESS in 1h 33m 02s'}, {'account_id': 17120, 'date': '2018-10-15 21:43:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

> @Manjeet: thanks for suggesting improvements, could you please
 > check the original comment from Bence (rubasov):
 > https://review.openstack.org/#/c/601600/2/neutron/conf/plugins/ml2/drivers/mech_sriov/agent_common.py@62
 > Here he suggested to use blacklist, and I feel that from admin's
 > perspective this is quite good, as no way that the admin
 > accidentaly tries to change the behaviour of a mech driver by
 > adding something which is not in the default driver specific
 > supported_vnic_types list.

IMO, restrictions can also be forced, like we can only add allowed types for each driver. let's say someone add a new type of supported nic, it will match with self.supported_nics or may be it can rename, current self.supported_nics to self._allowed_nics ! 

always set supported_nics to one from config if they all are within self.allowed_nics ? n case supported_nics are defined in config set 
supported_nics to allowed_nics of that mechanism ?"}, {'account_id': 8313, 'date': '2018-10-16 12:54:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

Manjeet: Some arguments on the side of blacklisting:

# the driver has a default supported_vnic_types list in the code level, and the admin has the right to change that from config, which makes harder to mess things.

# in case of upgrade to a version where the supported_vnic_types list is different on n+1 than on n, there is no need to change all the config files with the new vnic types (thanks to Gibi)'}, {'account_id': 27654, 'date': '2018-10-16 15:14:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15: Code-Review+1

I agreed on @Lajos Katona's arguement. The blacklist approach sounds better."}, {'account_id': 17120, 'date': '2018-10-16 22:40:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

> Manjeet: Some arguments on the side of blacklisting:
 > 
 > # the driver has a default supported_vnic_types list in the code
 > level, and the admin has the right to change that from config,
 > which makes harder to mess things.
 > 
 > # in case of upgrade to a version where the supported_vnic_types
 > list is different on n+1 than on n, there is no need to change all
 > the config files with the new vnic types (thanks to Gibi)

it depends if you want to keep the config same or different ? if you have same config for n+1 as n still updated not needed. likewise you can modify blacklist as well to block or make supported nics different in n+1 from n and it totally depends what cloud admin is upto.

in a case where supported vnics are same in n and n+1 no changes required in both cases.

I am not opposing this approach, I am ok with this if other reviewers feel okay with this, for just making it simple I came up with suggestions.'}, {'account_id': 8313, 'date': '2018-10-17 05:49:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

Manjeet: thanks for suggestion, let's wait for more reviews to have the opinion of others :-)"}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2018-10-17 08:41:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Code-Review+2

IMO this blacklist approach is good here. We give operators power to disable some types if they could break something.'}, {'account_id': 4694, 'date': '2018-10-19 22:39:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2018-10-20 18:01:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

commit_message:
supported_vnic_type configurable for ovs

Now supported_vnic_types is hardcoded to the mechanism drivers, but that
can depend on several factors, like type of the NIC, admin decision,
etc.
With this patch we put the right to decide which vnic types are
supported for ovs agent into the hands of the admin, by allowing
blacklisting items from the mechanism driver specific list.
Background: http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/neutron_qos/2018/
neutron_qos.2018-07-31-15.00.log.html#l-58

Change-Id: I63e562e2eccc5b02c1c767d6a2c28cb803131e99
Partial-Bug: #1578989
See-Also: https://review.openstack.org/502306 (nova spec)
See-Also: https://review.openstack.org/508149 (neutron spec)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-15 11:32:54.000000000', 'message': 'Prepare migration of base jobs to OSH-infra

Without this patch, openstack-helm-functional and
openstack-helm-multinode are a repetition of the
openstack-helm-infra-functional and openstack-helm-infra-multinode
jobs.

This is a problem, as multiple patches are required to change a
base job, and can lead to inconsistencies.

Instead the abstract jobs should be defined in only one place,
the openstack-helm-infra repositories. This will therefore be the
location of the openstack-helm project lint, functional, and
multinode "base" jobs.

From that point, openstack-helm-infra and openstack-helm can
implement their own job variants should this be required.

This patch fixes the link dependency between the two repositories
by ensuring all the OSH jobs are using their own local job
definition ("-temp" jobs) during the migration.

Change-Id: I3d3193415ba65d58c5dd9bbb1fc515f5399edece

commit_message:
Prepare migration of base jobs to OSH-infra

Without this patch, openstack-helm-functional and
openstack-helm-multinode are a repetition of the
openstack-helm-infra-functional and openstack-helm-infra-multinode
jobs.

This is a problem, as multiple patches are required to change a base
job, and can lead to inconsistencies.

Instead the abstract jobs should be defined in only one place, the
openstack-helm-infra repositories. This will therefore be the location
of the openstack-helm project lint, functional, and multinode "base"
jobs.

From that point, openstack-helm-infra and openstack-helm can implement
their own job variants should this be required.

This patch fixes the link dependency between the two repositories by
ensuring all the OSH jobs are using their own local job definition
("-temp" jobs) during the migration.

Change-Id: I3d3193415ba65d58c5dd9bbb1fc515f5399edece
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/610482
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/610488
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/611239

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-01 17:24:25.000000000', 'message': "Do not install centralized FIP if HA port is down

The issue scenario happens when we disassociate a floating IP
while the 'master' router host is restarted or powered-off.

When the L3 agent is powered-on again, the HA router state config
still remains 'master', but the ha port is down. And the message
queue still has one 'router_update' message (floating IP
disassociate message), so the L3 agent will sync this router info
at least twice during the restart, one is the router_update, the
other is the L3 agent full-sync.

The first one will add the centralized FIP to the qg-device, because
the router state is 'master'. So for DVR HA routers, only add the
centralized floating IP to the qg-device in the snat-namespace when
the HA port is up. For the restart procedure, if the HA port is up,
but the router is set to 'backup', do not add the floating IP.

Closes-Bug: #1794305
Change-Id: Ib39fe7dcd437a867c69852885c461a594167f6a1
(cherry picked from commit 656a8f872970013ff4c0bc577266cbe7f0343037)
"}]
commit_message:
Do not install centralized FIP if HA port is down

The issue scenario happens when we disassociate a floating IP
while the 'master' router host is restarted or powered-off.

When the L3 agent is powered-on again, the HA router state config
still remains 'master', but the ha port is down. And the message
queue still has one 'router_update' message (floating IP
disassociate message), so the L3 agent will sync this router info
at least twice during the restart, one is the router_update, the
other is the L3 agent full-sync.

The first one will add the centralized FIP to the qg-device, because
the router state is 'master'. So for DVR HA routers, only add the
centralized floating IP to the qg-device in the snat-namespace when
the HA port is up. For the restart procedure, if the HA port is up,
but the router is set to 'backup', do not add the floating IP.

Closes-Bug: #1794305
Change-Id: Ib39fe7dcd437a867c69852885c461a594167f6a1
(cherry picked from commit 656a8f872970013ff4c0bc577266cbe7f0343037)

commit_message:
Doc: update useful protection plugins for volume

Karbor support snapshot, freezer and glance protection
plugins for volume now. This patch update the doc.

Change-Id: I22d1d344cde7157ba46e52621dae374342c59609

subject: Add framework for watcher-status upgrade check
messages:
[{'account_id': 25553, 'date': '2018-10-18 21:52:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 13111, 'date': '2018-10-19 07:41:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

This patch fixes not only adding watcher-status CLI but also document structure to add CLI guide in the top page.

I recommend to devide this patch into two patches. One is adding watcher-status CLI. another is adding CLI guide in the top page.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-19 15:12:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Hidekazu: this is a pretty standard patch if you look at what's being added across all projects for this community-wide goal:

commit_message:
Add framework for watcher-status upgrade check

This commit adds the functionality of watcher-status CLI for performing
upgrade checks as part of the Stein cycle upgrade-checkers goal.
It only includes a sample check which must be replaced by real checks in
future.

Change-Id: Ic3d066af439797d6f705e805334f729b52ce3aac
Story: 2003657
Task: 26164

Add sqlalchemy migration in v2 for bp add-mysql-support-for-freezer

Add sqlalchemy migration frame in v2.
The test will be added in another patch.

commit_message:
swap out easily readable strings for constants

We define most all status in fields. So we should
try our best to reuse it to prevent spelling
mistakes.

Bring 'backing-up' and 'error_backing-up' status
from backup/api.py and backup/manager.py into
VolumeStatus of objects/fields.py.

Change-Id: Ibbd812d21c2cf73f228c10bbe062cf3c11d16799

Looks like we will need to merge https://review.openstack.org/#/c/611103/ (or similar) and update the hash for this release to include that.'}, {'account_id': 14352, 'date': '2018-10-23 14:37:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-10-24 02:34:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Published edit on patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-10-24 02:35:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Patchset 3 just updates the SHA to include 2fe63a4d74dcff34f7a0dc90ec65f3e0cc0bf596

 [tony@thor shade]$ git lol cc6ed396bfe8395f944c4498731377263d4012b6..origin/stable/queens
 * 2fe63a4 (origin/stable/queens, gerrit/stable/queens) Remove redundant target in README'}, {'account_id': 12898, 'date': '2018-10-24 02:52:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Looks good to me.

First Patchset had a +1 from Monty (PTL), the only difference between PS1 and PS2 is a rebase.  PS3 adds the needed fix to the README.  As 2fe63a4d74dcff34f7a0dc90ec65f3e0cc0bf596 was approved by Monty I'm taking that as a proxy for the whole release.

#Phew ;P"}]

commit_message:
Parallel erase disk devices

Currently we erase the disks one by one, which takes a long
time to finish, this patch adds support to the IPA so that
it can erase disks in parallel if told so.

Story: 1546949
Task: 11548
Co-Authored-By: yuan liang <leetpy2@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Kaifeng Wang <kaifeng.w@gmail.com>

Change-Id: If5cfb6ec000a654d07103c4b378d4c135249e238

commit_message:
Save store info for future client query

There's no store info listed when calling 'glance image-show' or
'glance -v image-list' currently. This patch is to save the store info
so it can be used in future query such as image-show and image-list.

Change-Id: I6bfdd92d5a76c752e8c761df00c5fa0263ff6a7a

commit_message:
Add test test_create_server_with_bdm_source_image

When booting a server, block-device can be specified
with source type image, volume or snapshot or blank.
Now bdm source type volume and snapshot have been covered
in testcases, and this is to add coverage for source type
image, for it is a basic function that is often required by
cloud users.

Change-Id: I24e6e7aa1cbebaf2d5e2fda4c65984f4a26bf6aa

There have been a number of fixes backported to Rocky
since its initial release.  This patch proposes Cinder
13.0.1 to release the numerous bug fixes.

commit_message:
Fix issue with first release logic

We need to use .get('releases') in order to get a None value back
instead of a KeyError, as is expected by the logic here.

Change-Id: Iaabf8dd309130ab609c26b01475cf5e0ae0a44dc

commit_message:
write_config: force utf8

When the Templates container some special characters like french
accents, we want to make sure we use utf8 encoding when writting the
config.

Closes-Bug: 1798820
Change-Id: Ic28c9eefb9c78bbc6fcc5c3af8b3ed7e14a91492
(cherry picked from commit 2575fbc8158d2511b95d708be3db2b2852ad1574)
